description: From Old French conjoindre, from Latin coniungo, from com- together + iungo join, equivalent to con- +â€Ž join.

entries.meaning: (grammar) One of the words or phrases that are coordinated by a conjunction.
(archaeology) A reassembled bone, stone or ceramic artifact.

verbs.description: conjoin (third-person singular simple present conjoins, present participle conjoining, simple past and past participle conjoined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To join together; to unite; to combine.
examples: They are representatives that will loosely conjoin a nation.
I will conjoin you in holy matrimony.

entries.meaning: (transitive, grammar) To join as coordinate elements, often with a coordinating conjunction, such as coordinate clauses.
(transitive, mathematics) To combine two sets, conditions, or expressions by a logical AND; to intersect.
(intransitive) To unite, to join, to league.
